what: Use the modes function to determine modality
title: cutoffvalue: An R Package for Cutoff Value Determination & Graphing
text: Evaluating objective valid cutoff value depends upon whether dataset bimodal. means modality dataset determined proceeding. null hypothesis test dataset unimodal; excess mass statistic associated p-value less 0.05 implies unimodal. strongly suggested run test prior function cutoffvalue; however, proceed depends knowledge understanding data. modes function uses example dataset (internal dataset object identified “cutoffvalue:::exampledata”) default. Thus, path dataset specified (e.g., running modes() console), data used. given label (.e., “modetest” example ), function returns Excess Mass statistic associated p-value Environment. Please keep mind default parameters cutoffvalue assume bimodal distribution - modalities may cause inaccuracies results. modes() function returns p-value excess mass statistic along instructions proceed based p-value. p-value less 0.05, accept alternative hypothesis (data least bimodal) proceed analysis. However, p-value 0.05, data unimodal following analyses entirely valid.
code: modetest <- modes(cutoffvalue:::exampledata) #> Modality Test Results: #>  - Excess mass = 0.097446  #>  - p-value = 0.002  #> **Reject null hypothesis** Distribution contains more than one mode; proceed with analyses. #>  #> Test Credit: Ameijeiras-Alonso et al. (2019) excess mass test

title: cutoffvalue: An R Package for Cutoff Value Determination & Graphing
text: likely want change following parameters match dataset preferences. nothing specified cutoffplot function, defaults used graph.
code: title <- "Plasma 11-KT levels in age-2 male spring chinook"  # Graph title xlab <- "Plasma [11-KT] (ng/mL)" # X-axis label cutofflab <- "Minijack cutoff" # label for cutoff value on graph cutoffunits <- "(ng/mL)" # units for cutoff value LowerMode_col <- "red" # line color for the lower mode LowerMode_lty <- 1 # line type for the lower mode LowerMode_lwd <- 2 # line width for the lower mode UpperMode_col <- "purple" # line color for the upper mode UpperMode_lty <- 1 # line type for the upper mode UpperMode_lwd <- 2 # line width for the upper mode cutoffvalue_col <- "black" # line color for the cutoff value cutoffvalue_lty <- 2 # line type for the cutoff value cutoffvalue_lwd <- 2 # line width for the cutoff value

previous_headings: Using two functions to determine modality and generate the final plot > Use the cutoffplot function to plot the final graph
title: cutoffvalue: An R Package for Cutoff Value Determination & Graphing
code: plotty <- cutoffplot(cutoffvalue:::exampledata, title, xlab, cutofflab, cutoffunits, LowerMode_col, LowerMode_lty, LowerMode_lwd, UpperMode_col, UpperMode_lty, UpperMode_lwd, cutoffvalue_col, cutoffvalue_lty, cutoffvalue_lwd)

title: Plot a histogram of the dataset that includes the curves for each mode and the cutoff value — cutoffplot
code: cutoffplot(   x = cutoffvalue:::exampledata,   title = "Plasma 11-KT levels in age-2 male spring chinook",   xlab = "Plasma [11-KT] (ng/mL)",   cutofflab = "Minijack cutoff",   cutoffunits = "ng/mL",   LowerMode_col = "red",   LowerMode_lty = 1,   LowerMode_lwd = 2,   UpperMode_col = "purple",   UpperMode_lty = 1,   UpperMode_lwd = 2,   cutoffvalue_col = "black",   cutoffvalue_lty = 2,   cutoffvalue_lwd = 2 )

title: Plot a histogram of the dataset that includes the curves for each mode and the cutoff value — cutoffplot
text: x data file; data organized single column log- natural log-transformed data without column header title Title graph, default blank xlab Label x-axis, default "Plasma 11-KT (ng/mL)" cutofflab Label cutoff value, default "Minijack cutoff" cutoffunits Label units, default "ng/mL"

title: Plot a histogram of the dataset that includes the curves for each mode and the cutoff value — cutoffplot
text: Returns histogram colored lines depicting curves upper lower modes along determined cutoff line delineate two modes. cutoff value also returned environment.

title: Plot a histogram of the dataset that includes the curves for each mode and the cutoff value — cutoffplot
code: plotty <- cutoffplot(cutoffvalue:::exampledata, "Example Graph Title", "Example X-Axis", "Cutoff Label", "UNITS") #> number of iterations= 21   #> number of iterations= 15   #> Cutoff Value: 0.1137313number of iterations= 19    #> number of iterations= 21   #> number of iterations= 18

what: Determines the modality of the dataset — modes
title: Determines the modality of the dataset — modes
text: function tests dataset's modality. uses modetest function multimode package written Ameijeiras-Alonso et al. (2019) determine excess mass test statistic test number modes. matter course, function runs cleanData function, negating need run separately.

title: Determines the modality of the dataset — modes

text: x data file; data organized single column log- natural log-transformed data without column header

title: Determines the modality of the dataset — modes
text: Returns p-value excess mass statistic determine whether dataset unimodal.

title: Determines the modality of the dataset — modes
code: modetest <- modes(cutoffvalue:::exampledata) #> Warning: A modification of the data was made in order to compute the excess mass or the dip statistic #> Warning: A modification of the data was made in order to compute the excess mass or the dip statistic #> Modality Test Results: #>  - Excess mass = 0.097447  #>  - p-value = 0.006  #> **Reject null hypothesis** Distribution contains more than one mode; proceed with analyses. #>  #> Test Credit: Ameijeiras-Alonso et al. (2019) excess mass test #>
